resources.string: AFM (Apostolic Faith Missions) Central Tabernacle is a church that follows pentecostal values. The head pastor of the church is pastor Harry Solomon who has been gifted the blessing of being a powerful preacher and leader of the church. He has studied and continues to study the word of God thoroughly and has a doctorate in theology.

In 1930, more than 20 years after the A.F.M of South Africa, which was founded in Johannesburg, that the gospel of Christ reached Stanger through believers who relocated to Stanger (now Kwadukuza). One of the believers, sister J Budge is assumed to have lost a five-pound note which was worth a lot in 1930. She promised the Lord that is the money was to be recovered, she would pay for the expenses for the holding of a gospel campaign amongst the town.

By faith, the money was found, and she kept her promise, the meeting had been arranged in a local Hindu hall, with Pastors Moody Wright and C.S Flewelling. the gospel was heard among the people and some converted. One of which as David F Williams who became a full-time worker and remain active in the Stanger Assembly until his retirement.

On the 16th of November 1930, 21 converts were baptised, on the 5th of October 1931, 88 were baptised. A month later, 1 November 1931, 20 more were added to the church. Meanwhile, services continued to be held at the Hindu hall, by Pastor C S Flewelling until 1933, when they moved to the P.W.D Hall. Building of the Stanger Church began in 1935 and on 20th of June 1937, it was officially opened.

The original A.F.M Central Tabernacle Stanger building was opened in 1937, today, it is a modern and spacious church which is able to accommodate 850 people. The new church building was opened in December of 1986, at a cost of more than R180 000 and today is filled by a large congregation.
